contentfulBlogPost.title: How and Why The COVID Tracking Project Built a Screenshot System

childMarkdownRemark.html: Julia Kodysh is Data Infrastructure co-lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

categories.name: How We Made The COVID Tracking Project

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: 20,000 Hours of Data Entry: Why We Didn’t Automate Our Data Collection

lede.lede: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Theo Michel is a Project Manager and contributor to Data Quality efforts at the Covid Tracking Project.
Rebma is an infrastructure engineer who likes puzzles, solving problems, and who did the data scripting and automation for The Covid Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Dating Data: How We Used Multiple Dating Schemes to Provide the Most Complete Picture of the Pandemic

lede.lede: Throughout our year of tracking COVID-19 tests, cases, and outcomes, we were confronted with data organized by numerous dating schemes. Here’s how we came to understand those dating schemes, and the solution we developed for making the best of them.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Julia Kodysh is Data Infrastructure co-lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How and Why The COVID Tracking Project Built a Screenshot System

lede.lede: A system for regularly capturing static images of state COVID-19 websites helped us produce an archive and verify our published data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Amanda French, Community Lead and Data Entry Shift Lead at The COVID Tracking Project, has a doctorate in English and is an expert in digital humanities.
Brian S.-K. Li has been a Data Entry and Data Quality Shift Lead at The COVID Tracking Project since May 2020 and is a student at Princeton University.

blog_post.title: Behind The COVID Tracking Project’s Public Help Desk

lede.lede: Volunteers and staffers at The COVID Tracking Project replied to thousands of messages from the public last year. Here’s why we took the trouble, and here’s what people wanted to know.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Amanda French, Community Lead and Data Entry Shift Lead at The COVID Tracking Project, has a doctorate in English and is an expert in digital humanities.
Nicki Camberg is a student journalist studying Political Science and Statistics at Barnard College, and the City Data Manager at CTP.

blog_post.title: Inside The COVID Tracking Project's Volunteer Organization

lede.lede: More than 800 volunteers performed thousands of hours of work to make our regular data operation possible during the COVID-19 pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rachel Glickhouse is a New York-based journalist who works on project management and impact tracking at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Measuring Our Impact at The COVID Tracking Project

lede.lede: Our largely volunteer-operated effort became a critical data source for journalists, scientists, academics and government officials.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

lede.lede: Looking back at what made The COVID Tracking Project work.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Theo Michel is a Project Manager and contributor to Data Quality efforts at the Covid Tracking Project.
Rebma is an infrastructure engineer who likes puzzles, solving problems, and who did the data scripting and automation for The Covid Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: (The Perils of) Automatically Collecting COVID Data

lede.lede: Automating data collection published by the states was an adventure full of trickery and misfortune.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Entered COVID-19 Testing and Outcomes Data Every Day for a Year

lede.lede: We set up a set of roles and a shift system to carefully gather and inspect the data we published.

blogContent.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"One of the basic principles behind The COVID Tracking Project has been the reliability and transparency of the data we collect and report. In service to that, we developed a system for taking screenshots of our original data sources, usually state COVID-19 information websites. We did this for a few reasons:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Data provenance","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": It was important to us to be able to show our work and where the data came from.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Data quality","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": We needed the ability to go back and check our work against what had been published on specific dates and answer questions like: “What testing and case counts did Massachusetts report on November 19, 2020?”","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Maintaining history","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": There are many situations where we needed to backfill or update data points in response to state data revisions. Capturing and saving old screenshots of state dashboards and sites allowed us to revisit them to trace such revisions.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Data annotations","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": We needed to be able to keep track of the changes that states would make to data definitions. Being able to refer back to the visual archive of a state website (as opposed to, say, a CSV) greatly increased our chances of preserving the kind of context that often appeared solely in notes or annotations on websites and dashboards.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Archival","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":": Eventually, we want to be able to present a record of what was reported and when, and have that record be as complete as possible.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"ordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"These requirements made website screenshots important to our goal to have the most complete, accurate, and trusted data set available. We considered existing resources for this, like the Wayback Machine, but did not find any that captured data as frequently or thoroughly as we needed to. So we created our own.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"How it started vs. how it’s going","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"When we first built a screenshot system, it was a quick and scrappy set of Python scripts. We assumed that all we would need to do is capture a basic screengrab of a website: take a URL, render it using an existing resource like ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://phantomjscloud.com/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"PhantomJSCloud","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", and save it as a PNG image. Things quickly grew more complex, and we had early hints of the need to customize our methods. Some examples:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In the early days, a frequent issue that cropped up (pun intended) was resizing certain sites: some screenshots would be cut off in the middle of the webpage, and the data we needed to screenshot happened to be at the bottom.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Some state sites had a pop-up box with different messages, like offering an email sign-up. With automated screenshotting, pop-up boxes often blocked data or grayed out the rest of the website.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As state websites moved more and more toward Power BI or Tableau dashboards, we increasingly ran into complex situations, such as waiting 60 seconds for a website to load, navigating to tab 13, and hovering over a certain element to display a data point.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"ordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Before we had a sense of how frequent and complex our customizations would need to be, we wrote in special cases for particular states directly into the code―like resizing a render view before capturing the screenshot. However, as more and more states required custom treatment, we realized we needed a more general solution for writing custom Javascript to navigate various situations.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Screenshot system details","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We collect screenshots for several of our datasets:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Core testing and outcomes data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/race"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"The COVID Racial Data Tracker","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/nursing-homes-long-term-care-facilities"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Long-Term-Care COVID Tracker","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\nScreenshots were collected by a ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots/blob/main/run-screenshots.py"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Python script","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" which ran as a cron job several times a day. The script used PhantomJSCloud to render a specific set of URLs and execute custom Javascript code when necessary. The screenshots were then timestamped and stored on Amazon S3. We made them accessible through the detailed view on each state page as well as on our ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://screenshots.covidtracking.com/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"screenshots website","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Here is an overview of our screenshots infrastructure:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"34Qlw9efMNnveDSzerPVlA","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"All of the screenshot system code is available on ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"GitHub","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Configuration","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Each state's screenshot configuration is stored in a YAML file, which contains one or more URLs with entries that look like this:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7v59rX4BnLBABtB3eMPRJI","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The \"name\" is a descriptive name for this particular link; for better or for worse, we settled on naming our screenshots primary/secondary/tertiary early in the project. Primary screenshots generally captured states’ main data sources, while additional screenshots captured data that required unique scripting. We then used PhantomJSCloud to render the given URL, and before taking a snapshot, we directed PhantomJSCloud to run the script specified in ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"code"}],"value":"overseerScript","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". In this case, we clicked on a particular tab within the dashboard, waited 10 seconds for the page to load, then took the snapshot. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We also modified the rendering settings for this page to be able to capture all of the relevant data. For more context on ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"code"}],"value":"clipRectangle","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" and other possible settings, check out the PhantomJSCloud ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://phantomjscloud.com/docs/http-api/interfaces/irendersettings.html#cliprectangle"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"documentation","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Lastly, we included a \"message\" for documentation purposes, to understand our special case behavior for that state.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We also built in a workaround to download data files directly rather than capture a screenshot. See an ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots/blob/main/configs/taco/RI.yaml#L10-L13"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"example config file","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"All of our config files backing screenshots can be found on GitHub in the Screenshots repository: ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots/tree/main/configs/taco"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"testing and outcomes data configs","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots/tree/main/configs/crdt"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"COVID Racial Data Tracker configs","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/COVID19Tracking/screenshots/tree/main/configs/ltc"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Long-Term-Care COVID Tracker configs","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Manual screenshots","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As we built out our data point coverage, we encountered various cases that were difficult to capture with the screenshot script. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The most common such case was Microsoft Power BI or Tableau dashboards that would load so slowly that we could not capture them even after instructing the script to wait several minutes. This problem was worse when states embedded these dashboards in their sites and did not enable the option for users to view them separately.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Another difficult case―and a nightmare for web accessibility―was when sites required visitors to click on or hover over buttons or chart objects to see the data. In some cases, we were able to direct the script to click on or hover over the object if it could be specified using DOM scripting or CSS selectors or if it remained stationary day-over-day and we could direct the script to the x,y coordinate point on the page. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A final example: when data points were published in reports with unpredictable names that could not be navigated to from the state websites. Predictable names might consist of a filename slug with the date the file was posted appended to it; an unpredictable name might include case or testing numbers in the URL. We managed to find workarounds and hacky tricks that allowed us to capture some data points that fell into all of these cases. Too often, though, we could not script these screenshots.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In the fall, to address cases in which we could not capture automatic screenshots, we began to take manual screenshots and post them in state-specific Slack threads during data entry shifts. After a few weeks, we decided to roll out a system for manual screenshots to augment our coverage and save our volunteers the task of spending hours―sometimes fruitlessly―to configure single screenshots for the most difficult data points. We spun up a system that would allow us to upload screenshots manually through our internal website and store them in Amazon S3, along with various scripts and bots that helped us track and validate these manual screenshots.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5xHhPKhJA1onwayi2YRXlj","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This portal allowed users to configure date and time, state, data type, and data subtype with buttons and dropdowns that automatically set the screenshot filename. In this example, the data type is “Testing & Outcomes” data (our core data entry) and the data subtype is “primary source,” denoting that this screenshot was taken of the page or dashboard that was our primary source for the state of Hawaii. Once users clicked Upload, the screenshot would be stored in the Amazon S3 bucket for the state and a bot would post to a thread in our data entry channel that the screenshot had been uploaded. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"At the height of the manual screenshot system, we captured 25 manual screenshots each day during core data entry. Different volunteers could submit screenshots for each state, so we kept processes simple. Volunteers knew which screenshots to capture by referring to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/5/d/e/2PACX-1vRpgAzsSuN9BGtPv8DXMoct3lIRSpmHeFzzI0J7Sc1Ym68RP89QTSFJp4UBFuPMxpdlHpAGKBOtLHIG/pubhtml"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"source notes","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", pop-up notes on our data entry sheet that informed volunteers where to find metrics. An example source note with screenshot instructions is below:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"HI primary > tab \"ICU Beds and Ventilators\" > graph \"Trends: COVID+ ICU Beds in Use\" > hover over most recent date","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"note: please screenshot the number on the hover graph until we figure out screenshots!","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"screenshot: https://internal.covidtracking.com/screenshot?state=HI&datatype=taco&subtype=primary-source","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"blockquote"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The link in the source note would take the volunteer to the internal website page with the appropriate options preselected with the URL parameters. The volunteer would simply need to capture the screenshot, navigate to the link in the source notes, select the correct file on their computer, and hit Upload. The page would autofill the date and time when the volunteer visited it, though the option remained to select date and time in order to allow for historical screenshots to be uploaded.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To ensure that all manual screenshots correctly captured the right metrics, one designated volunteer would double-check all the screenshots. We built a script that would find all instances of screenshot source notes in our data entry source notes sheet and would write them to a manual screenshot checking sheet, allowing the double-checker to check off when each screenshot had been uploaded and validated during the shift. In tandem with the Slack bot that notified when each screenshot was uploaded, this screenshot checking sheet made verifying manual screenshots a breeze.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6JueIhpJjWdXdjaeLFMakI","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Human maintenance","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Keeping screenshots functional and up-to-date was a tedious and time-consuming task. States frequently changed dashboards and data pages, added new metrics, or removed metrics. Sometimes the data entry team switched sources around within state sites based on the recommendation of our data quality team. Screenshots occasionally broke and needed maintenance. To accommodate these changes, we devised processes to ensure that our screenshots worked and were up-to-date.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Once a week, a small team would meet to check screenshots using a tracker sheet that mirrored our source notes for each data point. For all 56 states and territories that we tracked, volunteers would select screenshot status for each data point. Volunteers could choose from a number of dropdown options to record whether the data point was captured in a screenshot, and if so, in which one. Among the options were “primary” through “quinary” to indicate which screenshot contained the data point (owing to our decision to name script-captured screenshots sequentially), N/A Manual Screenshot, and various other options to indicate coverage or the fact that we did not need to worry about coverage.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"If volunteers found a data point that was not covered by our screenshots or encountered a broken screenshot, they would submit a “To Do” ticket using a Slack workflow and list the state, the data point to be captured, and a description of the problem. Screenshot maintainers worked mostly asynchronously and tackled these to-dos as they popped up. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"On March 6, the day before we ended data collection, we reached 100% coverage of our 797 core testing and outcomes data points.","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" Reaching that milestone required hundreds of scripted screenshots, dozens of manual screenshots, and huge amounts of volunteers’ time.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Takeaways","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We learned a lot in both building and evolving a system to capture images of state COVID-19 data websites. This project was a half-structured-data capture: we aimed to preserve a human view of the state COVID-19 data, though to get at the relevant human-viewable website section, we often needed to structure how we arrived there. While in some cases we used the screenshot system to download data files, the goal remained to capture snapshots of the data that people could scan visually.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Absent more concrete federal guidelines for data reporting, the COVID-19 data landscape was a patchwork of idiosyncratic state data pages and dashboards. Many states published data on sites with severe accessibility issues. Some states published metrics across many pages and dashboards, while others constrained them to a single site. Tableau and Microsoft Power BI were widely used; we had to reverse-engineer these dashboards to get at the data we needed, accidentally developing a brain trust of dashboard-scripting manipulations. To capture screenshots of our data sources required flexibility, tenacity, and a team of committed contributors ready to address any possible issue with states’ reporting.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Ultimately, what we built is a kind of general purpose website screenshots engine. For any future data collection project that relies on maintaining provenance, history, and accuracy of data, we recommend developing or using this kind of system early in the project, since data transparency and accountability only becomes more important over time.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Acknowledgements","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Data quality contributors―including Jesse Anderson, Elizabeth Eads, Jonathan Gilmour, Hannah Hoffman, Michal Mart, Theo Michel, Brandon Park, Kayleigh Van Poolen, and more―kept our screenshots fresh by checking them for issues and coverage.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Screenshot maintainers―including Jesse Anderson, Jonathan Gilmour, Hannah Hoffman, Julia Kodysh, Zach Lipton, Michal Mart, Theo Michel, Charlotte Minsky, Kara Schechtman, Andrew Schwartz, and Josh Zarrabi―wrote and maintained our screenshot config files.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Jonathan Gilmour, Hannah Hoffman, Elliott Klug, Michal Mart, and Quang Nguyen built processes and tooling for tracking screenshot quality.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Kevin Miller spun up internal and external screenshots websites and built the manual screenshot slackbot affectionately known as Manual Screenbot.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Julia Kodysh built the screenshots system and infrastructure.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

image.title: Screenshots infrastructure flowchart
image.description: A flowchart diagram describes our screenshot architecture. The main screenshot script, written in Python, runs on an AWS EC2 instance. The script pulls from YAML configs on GitHub and makes API calls to PhantomJSCloud. Screenshots are stored in an Amazon S3 bucket. A manual screenshots portal also sends screenshots to the same S3 bucket. The COVID Tracking Project website pulls from the screenshots datastore to display screenshots.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
- name: tertiary
  url: https://adem.maps.arcgis.com/apps/...
  overseerScript: |
    page.manualWait();
    await page.waitForSelector("span.ember-view.tab-title:nth-of-type(5)");
    page.click("span.ember-view.tab-title:nth-of-type(5)");
    await page.waitForDelay(10000);
    page.done();
  renderSettings: 
    clipRectangle:
      height: 1400
      width: 1400
  message: clicking on "Tests" tab for AR tertiary

image.title: Upload portal
image.description: Portal to upload a file with options to configure date and time, state, data type, and testing and outcomes data subtype, from which a filename is constructed. A screenshot of Hawaii’s ICU and Ventilator dashboard has been uploaded and appears in a box that allows image editing. A blue “Upload” button is at the bottom of the portal.

image.title: Screenshot spreadsheet
image.description: Spreadsheet with rows that contain descriptions of data points that need manual screenshots. Checkboxes at the end of each row turn green when checked to denote if that particular manual screenshot has been uploaded and validated.

lede.lede: A system for regularly capturing static images of state COVID-19 websites helped us produce an archive and verify our published data.
